sentences.sentence: Regrettably, the "act now, think later" mentality rampant in our community appears to embrace any posting on social media or complaint reported in the news media as uncontroverted truth.
Lives are ruined and reputations tarnished by the push of an "enter" key.

Justice Russell Brown, an esteemed member of our highest court, is the most recent victim of the current climate of rushing to judgment.What is both incomprehensible and troubling is that much of what actually transpired in Arizona before, during and after the incident is publicly accessible.
The media have either blatantly spun the facts to sensationalize or have purposely avoided an analysis of the unassailable facts.
It is patently obvious upon a meaningful evaluation that any allegation of misconduct is entirely lacking in substance.

It is truly stunning that Justice Brown is under attack.Even a cursory review of police video footage, the 911 call and Instagram posts, reveals blatant inconsistencies and conflicting accounts of what was alleged to have occurred.
On an unbiased assessment, not burdened by preconceptions or media hysteria, any criticism of Justice Brown can only be characterized as "much ado about absolutely nothing.
"The publicly available facts reveal that Justice Brown, following a black tie gala event in which he paid tribute to a former member of the Court, was having a drink in his hotel lounge.
A nearby table of guests, which included three women and a male companion, invited him to join them and they engaged in conversation.
The entire group left together and proceeded in the direction of their rooms, across a large public space.

As they approached the pool, in an open patio area, the intoxicated and belligerent male companion, who was a former U.S. Marine, engaged in a physical assault on Justice Brown.The media has twisted this unprovoked assault into something it is clearly not.

From unfair and misleading headlines of drunken brawls, to the offensive comparison of Justice Brown to a skunk, the press has amazingly ignored the easily accessible truth in favour of rancorous gossip, easy fodder for the distorted "court" of public opinion.In comparing Justice Brown to a skunk, the Toronto Star's Heather Mallick referred(https://www.thestar.com/opinion/star-columnists/2023/03/15/from-rigid-and-rule-bound-to-roguish-and-free-range.html?rf) to the assaulter as a "gentlemanly ex-marine" and "quite reasonable," apparently relying upon a tweet containing thirty seconds of police footage.

This extract was, in fact, taken from a forty-nine-minute video during which this "gentleman" was characterized by the attending police officer as having a "hostile attitude," "aggressive demeanor," and was "about two seconds away from getting charged with disorderly conduct."

The officer's comments resulted from the "gentleman" repeatedly swearing at the officer, challenging his authority and threatening him.It is notable that following the assault on Justice Brown, the ex-Marine and his cohorts proceeded to Google him and consider their cover-up for an hour prior to police involvement.
They then launched a public campaign, conducting interviews and contacting the Judicial Council.

One of the women who was with the former Marine quite incredibly posted the following message on her public Instagram account: "I'd like to personally thank the country of Canada for an unforgettable and complimentary girls trip."
She considers this event, one from which she suggests she has financially benefitted from, as a joke.
Her travelling companion commented, further undermining their collective credibility, by posting a series of emojis which included two fists and ending with a bag of money.
(The initial post was later removed for "user safety purposes,"(https://www.instagram.com/p/CoKTCn2ujfd/) but screenshots of the original exist.

)Disorder in the court: What happens when scandal hits the Supreme Court of Canada(https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/supreme-court-canada-russell-brown-scanda-explainer)Michael Higgins: Why Canadians were never good enough for Justin Trudeau(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/michael-higgins-why-canadians-were-never-good-enough-for-justin-trudeau)The Judicial Council has had six weeks to review and investigate these petty "allegations."
Whatever more time and effort is required for the Council to conclude its investigation, that should no longer keep Justice Brown from returning to the bench where he belongs.
The media must stop perpetuating falsehoods, and relying upon what Justice Peter Cory once characterized as "an innuendo of suspicion.
"The facts, properly investigated and sensibly considered cannot possibly lead anyone to suggest that Justice Brown should be subject to discipline.
The cases before the Supreme Court are obviously of national importance and the Court's rulings can set legal precedents that stand for decades.
We are entitled to our full complement of justices to hear cases, participate in deliberations and to render judgments.

The public interest is served by returning Justice Brown to the work he is eminently qualified to do.Brian Greenspan practices criminal law at Greenspan, Humphrey Weinstein LLP, Toronto, is the founding chair of the Canadian Council of Criminal Defence Lawyers and the recipient of an Honorary Doctor of Laws from the Law Society of Ontario.
Julianna Greenspan practices criminal law at Greenspan Partners LLP, Toronto, and is on the Board of the Canadian Civil Liberties Association !
@COPYRIGHT=© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
